description: In four years, the new regime has made Afghan women and girls entirely invisible, aided by the silence of the international community, criticize three human rights activists in an opinion piece for Le Monde.

headline: In Serbia, the protest movement has turned violent, triggered by government provocations
description: President Aleksandar Vucic is facing accusations of sending hooligan groups to suppress the anti-corruption movement that has shaken the country for the past nine months.

headline: A well-orchestrated response to illegal music downloads
description: 'Click To Pirate' (5/5). The music industry, the first cultural sector hit by large-scale piracy, has found an effective defense in paid streaming. Yet some internet users remain resistant to this evolution.

headline: A winemaker, his daughter and a vintage for their undocumented workers
description: In southeastern France, Philippe Grisard and his daughter, Nadège, rely daily on undocumented workers to help tend their vineyard. To draw attention to their workers' precarious legal status, they named one of their vintages 'Sans eux' ('Without Them').

headline: Who's going to lie down on the couch? 'The Sopranos,' the first TV series to tackle mental health
description: 'Breaking The Script' (3/5). In 1999, the TV series 'The Sopranos' introduced viewers to a mafia boss suffering from depression. Through the intense exchanges between this anti-hero and his therapist, mental health became a central theme on television for the first time, where it has continued to thrive ever since.

headline: Hackers versus sports broadcasters: A tight match to win over viewers
description: 'Click To Pirate' (4/5). Hit later than other sectors by the scourge of piracy, the sports industry now faces a proliferation of illegal broadcasts, from Telegram to IPTV. Meanwhile, users of streaming platforms criticize what they see as inadequete legal offerings.
